entranceFees.description:
There are no fees to visit the park.

Qualifying visitors may obtain any of the passes for which there is no charge. These passes include the Access Pass (persons with a permanent disability), Military Pass (active military) and Every Kid Outdoors (4th graders with a printed voucher from www.everykidoutdoors.gov)
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: Appomattox Court House NHP is located 3 miles east of U.S. Highway 460, and 3 miles east of the modern town of Appomattox, Virginia along Rt. 24.
data.weatherInfo: The park may close due to emergency weather conditions (typically snow or ice).  For updated information about possible closure or altered hours due to weather, please call 434-352-8987 ext. 245.

operatingHours.description: The park is open daily from 9-5, with the exception of certain holidays: Thanksgiving Day, December 25, and January 1. The park may have reduced hours (9-2) on December 24 and 31.

data.description: On April 9, 1865, the surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia in the McLean House in the village of Appomattox Court House, Virginia signaled the end of the nation's largest war. Two important questions about its future were answered. Could the nation survive a civil war intact, and would that nation exist without slavery? The answer to both was yes and a new nation was born.

images.altText: This is the home where Gen. Lee surrendered to Gen. Grant on April 9, 1865
images.title: The McLean House
images.caption: This is the home where Gen. Lee surrendered to Gen. Grant on April 9, 1865

images.altText: The McLean House during the 150th Anniversary with luminaries along the Stage Road.
images.title: The McLean House during the 150th Anniversary
images.caption: The McLean House during the 150th Anniversary with luminaries along the Stage Road.

images.credit: Photo by Cameron Davidson (permission for NPS use)

data.directionsInfo:
The Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center is located in Nome, AK. Nome, AK is not on the road system and may be reached via a commercial flight. The Bering Land Bridge Visitor Center is located about a mile from Nome Airport. 

Bering Land Bridge National Preserve is located in the northern portion of the Seward Peninsula. There are no roads or trails into the parklands. Logistics on how to reach Bering Land Bridge is based on an individual’s resources and abilities.
data.weatherInfo: Weather in the Seward Peninsula is generally characterized by long freezing winters and short, cool summers. Coastal areas typically have mild weather, while the interior has greater seasonal variation in temperature and precipitation.
data.name: Bering Land Bridge

operatingHours.description: Bering Land Bridge Preserve is open 24/7 year round. Due to its remote location accessing the preserve can be challenging, costly and time consuming.
operatingHours.name: Bering Land Bridge National Preserve

data.description: Bering Land Bridge National Preserve lies at the continental crossroads that greatly influenced the distribution of life in the Western Hemisphere during the Pleistocene Epoch. It is a vital landscape for indigenous communities who depend on the land just as their ancestors did for many generations. It is a wild and ecologically healthy landscape unlike any other.

images.altText: Flock of shore birds taking flight
images.title: Flock of shore birds
images.caption: Flock of shore birds taking flight

images.altText: A hiker is seen in the distance as autumn colors dominate the tundra landscape.
images.title: Fall Colors
images.caption: Autumn hike at Bering Land Bridge

images.altText: Three wet muskox stand in a line.
images.title: Wet Muskox
images.caption: Three wet muskox.

images.altText: Rolling sand dunes with sparse vegetation with full moon rising above.
images.title: Coastal Moon Rise
images.caption: Coastal moon rise

entranceFees.description: Big Hole is fee free! We do sell the Lifetime Senior Pass, the Annual Senior Pass, and the America the Beautiful Annual Pass, and issue the Access Pass to those that qualify.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fees

data.directionsInfo:
Big Hole National Battlefield is located on Highway 43 ten miles west of the town of Wisdom in southwestern Montana.

Bear Paw Battlefield is located on Route 240 sixteen miles south of the town of Chinook in north-central Montana.

entrancePasses.description: There are no entrance fees to Big Hole National Battlefield or Bear Paw Battlefield. However, the we sell the Annual Senior Pass, the Lifetime Senior Pass, and the America the Beautiful Annual Pass, and issue the Access Pass to those that qualify at the Big Hole National Battlefield's visitor center.
entrancePasses.title: Entrance Passes

data.weatherInfo: This climatic region is typified by large seasonal temperature differences, with warm to hot (and often humid) summers and cold (sometimes severely cold) winters. Wisdom has a humid continental climate.
data.name: Big Hole

operatingHours.description: Following guidance from the White House, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and state and local public health authorities, Big Hole National Battlefield is increasing recreational access. The NPS is working  with federal, state, and local public health authorities to closely monitor the COVID-19 pandemic and using a phased approach to increase access on a park-by-park basis. Beginning July 29, 2020, the visitor center will be open Wed - Sun, 9:00am-5:00pm, while the rest of the park is open daily.
operatingHours.name: Big Hole National Battlefield Visitor Center

data.description: On August 9, 1877 gun shots shattered a chilly dawn on a sleeping camp of Nez Perce. By the time the smoke cleared on August 10, almost 90 Nez Perce were dead along with 31 soldiers and volunteers. Big Hole National Battlefield was created to honor all who were there.

images.altText: Multiple tepee poles and a river are silhouetted against a dawn sky.
images.title: Battlefield at Dawn
images.caption: Today tepee poles stand sentinel at the site of August 9th, 1877 dawn attack at the Big Hole.

images.altText: Blue camas flowers dot a green field with tepee poles in the background.
images.title: Camas Blooms Near the Nez Perce Camp at the Big Hole
images.caption: The Nez Perce chose their camp site in the Big Hole in part due to the Camas, whose roots they gathered prior to the August 9th attack.

images.altText: a cannon overlooks a valley and distant mountains
images.title: Mountain Howitzer at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.caption: Nez Perce warriors captured and dismantled the Mountain Howitzer cannon before the US army could use it effectively at the Battle of the Big Hole.

images.altText: cross country skis rest against a large granite monument on a snowy day.
images.title: Monument to the US Soldiers and Volunteers at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.caption: In 1883 the United States Government erected this monument in honor of the soldiers and volunteers that served and died at the 1877 Battle of the Big Hole.

images.altText: Stone carving of a Nez Perce Warrior's head in full regalia.
images.title: Chief Joseph Memorial at the Big Hole Battlefield
images.caption: This monument, erected on the Big Hole Battlefield in 1928, reads; "To the everlasting memory of the brave warriors Chief Joseph's Band who fought on these grounds in the Nez Perce War of 1877."

images.altText: Three large stone monuments and four interpretive signs overlook a series of low hills.
images.title: Bear Paw Battlefield

phoneNumbers.description: This is the best way to contact us. A park ranger is available 7 days a week during business hours to answer your questions about the park. The visitor center is closed Thanksgiving, December 25th and January 1st.

emailAddresses.description: For a quicker response please call the Parkway Visitor Center at 1-800-305-7417. A park ranger is available 7 days a week during business hours to answer your questions about the park. The visitor center is closed Thanksgiving, December 25th and January 1st.

entranceFees.description:
Brice's Cross Roads National Battlefield Site is free.

The Mississippi’s Last Stands Visitor and Interpretive Center is open 9 a.m. -5 p.m. Tuesday-Saturday. Admission is $5 for adults and $2 for children under 12 years old. Group rates are available.
entranceFees.title: No entrance fee

data.directionsInfo: Brices Cross Roads National Battlefield Site can be found 15 miles north of Tupelo, Mississippi. Exit U.S. Highway 45 onto Mississippi 370, in Baldwyn, Mississippi. The battlefield is located 6 miles west of Baldwyn, on Mississippi 370. Visitors may also consider visiting the Mississippi's Final Stands Interpretive Center in Baldwyn. Exit U.S. Highway 45 at Mississippi 370 and turn east. Take the first right off of Highway 370 to the interpretive center.
data.weatherInfo: Mississippi is classified as a humid subtropical climate, the weather ranges from mild winters to hot summers with high humidity between May and September. Average high temperatures reach into the high 80's in summer, and into the high 40's in winter. Check local forecasts to plan your trip.
data.name: Brices Cross Roads

operatingHours.description: The grounds of the Brices Cross Roads National Battlefield Site are open sunrise to sunset everyday of the year.
operatingHours.name: Brices Crossroads National Battlefield Site

data.description: The Confederate victory at Brices Cross Roads was a significant victory for Major General Nathan Bedford Forrest, but its long term effect on the war proved costly for the Confederates. Brices Cross Roads is an excellent example of winning the battle, but losing the war.

images.altText: The monument with cannons on each side
images.title: Brices Crossroads Monument
images.caption: The Confederate victory at Brices Cross Roads was a significant victory for Major General Nathan Bedford Forrest, but its long term effect on the war proved costly for the Confederates. Brices Cross Roads is an excellent example of winning the battle, bu

data.fullName: Brices Cross Roads National Battlefield Site

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for the park.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo:
The recommended route to the park is from Highway 191 in Chinle then turning east on Route 7. The park entrance and Visitor Center is about 3 miles from Highway 191.

An alternative is entering the park on the East side via Route 64. There are 3 overlooks to stop at along Route 64 before getting to the Visitor Center.

Travel on Route 7 from the East is NOT RECOMMENDED since the road is unpaved and unmaintained between Sawmill and the Spider Rock turnoff.
data.weatherInfo: Canyon de Chelly is located at 5,500 feet.  Spring is cool and windy; highs from 50 to 70; lows of 35 degrees.  Expect dust storms and canyon flooding. Summer is hot and dry; highs from 85 to 100; lows of 51 degrees.  Drink plenty of water outdoors. Fall is warm and often wet; highs from 60 to 80; lows of 40 degrees.  Expect lightning, thunderstorms, and flash floods. Winter is cold and breezy; highs from 40 to 60; lows of 18 degrees. Expect 1-4 inches of snow and freezing nighttime temperatures.
data.name: Canyon de Chelly

operatingHours.description: North Rim Drive, South Rim Drive, 10 overlooks and White House Trail remain open all year round.
operatingHours.name: Rim Drives, Overlooks and White House Trail

data.description: For nearly 5,000 years, people have lived in these canyons - longer than anyone has lived uninterrupted anywhere on the Colorado Plateau.  In the place called Tsegi, their homes and images tell us their stories. Today, Navajo families make their homes, raise livestock, and farm the lands in the canyons. A place like no other, the park and Navajo Nation work together to manage the land's resources.

images.altText: Farm in the canyon
images.title: Canyon Farm
images.caption: Navajo families continue to live and farm in the canyon they call Tsegi

images.altText: Hiking in the canyon
images.title: Canyon Hike
images.caption: Visitors can enjoy a free ranger led hike into the canyon

images.altText: View of Spider Rock from the overlook
images.title: Spider Rock
images.caption: Her home on top of Spider Rock, Spider Woman taught the Navajo people how to weave

images.altText: View of the canyon from the White House Trail
images.title: Canyon View
images.caption: The Navajo people call the canyon Tsegi meaning "within the rocks"

images.altText: View of White House Ruin
images.title: White House
images.caption: Ancient Puebloans built villages like White House that offered opportunities for trade, ceremony, and social gatherings.

addresses.line1: 3 miles E of Highway 191 on Route 7

entranceFees.description: There is no fee required to visit Cape Krusenstern National Monument
entranceFees.title: Free Entrance

data.directionsInfo: Cape Krusenstern National Monument lies within a remote area of northwest Alaska and is bordered by the Arctic Ocean and Chukchi Sea.  Visitors generally access the monument via the regional hub in Kotzebue. Commercial airlines provide daily service from Anchorage to Kotzebue. Chartered flights with licensed air taxi services, booked in advance, can take backcountry travelers to remote destinations within the monument.
data.weatherInfo: Snow, rain, and freezing temperatures can occur any time of the year. Always travel with good quality rain gear and warm layers. Be especially careful to stay dry. Hypothermia can set in on a windy, wet day, even when it doesn't feel that cold.
data.name: Cape Krusenstern

operatingHours.description: Since there are no roads into Cape Krusenstern National Monument, the visitor center is located in Kotzebue, AK.  From Kotzebue, visitors will charter an air taxi to transport them into the actual national monument which is open 24/7 every day of the year.
operatingHours.name: Cape Krusenstern National Monument

data.description: North of the Arctic Circle, the monument forms 70 miles of shoreline on the Chukchi Sea.  More than 114 beach ridges provide evidence of human use for 5,000 years.  The Inupiat continue to use the area today.  Vast wetlands provide habitat for shorebirds from as far away as South America.  Hikers and boaters can see carpets of wildflowers among shrubs containing wisps of qiviut from muskoxen.

images.altText: muskox standing on the tundra
images.title: Muskox and Geese
images.caption: Muskox and Greater White-fronted Geese on vegetated beach ridges in front of the Igichuk Hills.

images.altText: moon over snow covered hills
images.title: Winter Moon
images.caption: January light and a bright moon at 2 pm over the Igichuk Hills in Cape Krusenstern National Monument.

images.altText: aerial view of beach ridges
images.title: Beach Ridges on the Shore of Cape Krusenstern
images.caption: Beach ridges created by years of wave action during storms can be seen as parallel lines in the fall vegetation covering the old gravel.

images.altText: fish hanging on rack
images.title: Fish on a Drying Rack
images.caption: Pike (left and right) and trout (middle) dry on a rack at a subsistence camp. The slash marks allow more air to circulate and dry the meat more quickly.

images.altText: archaeologist digging
images.title: Old House Uncovered
images.caption: A University of Washington archeology crew conducts research on an old semi-subterranean house along the beach ridges of Cape Krusenstern. Old house timbers are slowly revealed about 4 feet down

entranceFees.description:
Cedar Creek and Belle Grove National Historical Park is a no fee park for the interim visitor contact station and ranger led programs. Therefore, the America the Beautiful-National Parks Pass discounts do not apply.

Our partner sites are non-profit organizations and do not receive federal funding from the National Park Service. Therefore, The America the Beautiful-National Parks Pass discounts DO NOT apply at partner sites. This includes all of the America the Beautiful Passes.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fees

data.directionsInfo: The National Park Service Visitor Contact Station is located at 7712 Main Street, Middletown, Virginia 22645 in the Middletown Courts plaza. The park is located near the intersection of Interstates 81 and 66 in the northern Shenandoah Valley.
data.weatherInfo:
Summers in Virginia are often very hot with high heat indexes. Check the weather in advance of your trip, and plan accordingly. Dress for the heat and for sun protection. Pack lots of water.

The Shenandoah Valley experiences temperate spring and fall seasons and winters with snowfall and cold temperatures.
data.name: Cedar Creek & Belle Grove

operatingHours.description:
Cedar Creek and Belle Grove NHP is closed on Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day.  

We have reduced winter hours from fall into spring, typically November - April. 

Always call ahead, especially during the winter, to make sure the Visitor Contact Station is open.  We have a limited staff and sometimes we  close due to unforeseen circumstances.
operatingHours.name: Cedar Creek and Belle Grove NHP Visitor Contact Station

data.description: The Shenandoah Valley invites you to learn about its rich heritage, from Native Americans who first shaped the land, to pioneers of this frontier; this fertile area became one of the most important wheat producing regions of the entire South. The Valley also witnessed some of the most dramatic events of the Civil War,including the Battle of Cedar Creek, a decisive October 19, 1864 Union victory.

images.altText: Sunrise over Belle Grove
images.title: Sunrise over Belle Grove
images.caption: Sunrise over Belle Grove

images.title: The Heater House
images.caption: The Heater House

images.title: Cedar Creek and Belle Grove in a Box
images.caption: Ranger Shannon presents Cedar Creek and Belle Grove in a Box.

images.title: Signal Knob Program

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee to visit the Channel Islands National Park.
entranceFees.title: Entrance

data.directionsInfo: While the mainland visitor center in Ventura is readily accessible by car or public transportation, the islands are only accessible by park concessionaire boats and planes or private boat. Advanced planning is highly recommended.
data.weatherInfo: In general, the islands have a Mediterranean climate year-round. Temperatures are relatively stable, with highs averaging in the mid-60s (°F) and lows in the low-50s. However, there are seasonal differences that visitors should take into consideration when visiting the park. In addition, visitors also should be aware that ocean and weather conditions vary considerably from day-to-day and island-to-island. For more information visit: http://www.nps.gov/chis/planyourvisit/weather.htm
data.name: Channel Islands

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day. Services and facilities have separate hours. Please see descriptions of those facilities elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Channel Islands National Park

data.description: Channel Islands National Park encompasses five remarkable islands and their ocean environment, preserving and protecting a wealth of natural and cultural resources. Isolation over thousands of years has created unique animals, plants, and archeological resources found nowhere else on Earth and helped preserve a place where visitors can experience coastal southern California as it once was.

images.altText: Steep, rugged ocean cliffs extending in an island chain.
images.title: Inspiration Point by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Inspiration Point, Anacapa Island: One of the most spectacular views in the park can be found from Inspiration Point. Looking to the west, one may see Middle and West Anacapa, with Santa Cruz Island in the distance.

images.altText: Yellow flowers in foreground extending out along a rocky coastline to a natural arch.
images.title: Arch Point by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Arch Point, Santa Barbara Island: With winter rains, the coreopsis emerges from summer's dormancy with light green foliage and bright yellow daisy-like flowers

images.altText: Pine tree high on a ridge overlooking a bay with blue water and white sand beach.
images.title: Torrey Pines by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Torrey Pines, Santa Rosa Island: Torrey pines occur naturally in only two locations throughout the world--on the cool, fog drenched northeastern slopes of Bechers Bay and just north of San Diego.

images.altText: Brown seals and sea lions on white sand beach with blue water and partly cloudy sky.
images.title: Point Bennet by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Point Bennet, San Miguel Island: One of the greatest concentrations of wildlife in the world occurs on San Miguel with over 100,000 pinnipeds gathering to breed, pup, and rest.

images.altText: Rust and grey colored fox in green grass.
images.title: Island Fox by Tim Hauf
images.caption: Island Fox, Santa Cruz Island: Thousands of years of isolation in a unique island environment has resulted in the development of the endemic island fox, a dwarf form of the mainland gray fox.

data.directionsInfo:
The park has numerous access points. There is no main entrance.

In Washington, DC, the C&O Canal begins in Georgetown on 29th Street NW, south of M Street, and runs alongside Canal Road / Clara Barton Parkway out of DC to the west.

The entrance to Great Falls Tavern is at Canal Road and MacArthur Blvd in Montgomery County, MD.

Park headquarters is located off I-70 exit 32B in Hagerstown, MD.

Williamsport Visitor center is off I-81 at exit 2, near the I-80/I-76 interchange.

See the maps page for more.

entrancePasses.description:
Valid for one full year from the month of purchase. Permits access to Great Falls Park, Virginia and the Great Falls area of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal National Historical Park on the Maryland side of the Potomac River. The annual pass allows entrance for the pass holder and additional passengers in a single private non-commercial vehicle, or pass holder plus three adults when entering on foot or bicycle.

Purchase online: https://www.recreation.gov/sitepass/111897
entrancePasses.title: Great Falls Annual Pass

data.weatherInfo: The Washington, DC, area has a four-season Mid-Atlantic climate. Summertime is warm and humid, while winter can be cold and snowy. Precipitation averages 2-4” monthly, year-round. The climate gradually gets cooler and wetter further west along the canal where the elevation is higher.
data.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

operatingHours.description: The towpath is open 365 days a year.
operatingHours.name: C&O Canal Towpath

data.description: Preserving America's early transportation history, the C&O Canal began as a dream of passage to Western wealth. Operating for nearly 100 years the canal was a lifeline for communities along the Potomac River as coal, lumber, and agricultural products floated down the waterway to market. Today it endures as a pathway for discovering historical, natural, and recreational treasures.

images.altText: Park sign in front of the historic Bowles House
images.title: Hancock Visitor Center (Bowles House)
images.caption: One of seven Park visitor centers, the Bowles House sits along an empty canal bed in Hancock.

images.altText: Fog over the Potomac River alongside the Canal towpath.
images.title: Big Slackwater
images.caption: Big Slackwater is a 3 mile stretch where canal boats entered the Potomac River to travel above Dam 4.

images.altText: A whitewashed lockhouse sits above a stone lock with wooden crib.
images.title: Lockhouse 16 along the Canal
images.caption: Lockhouse 16 sits atop a stone outcropping above the lock.

images.altText: A single bike rider on the towpath next to the widewater section of the canal.
images.title: Bike rider along the towpath
images.caption: The towpath offers a serene bike riding experience.

images.altText: The rushing river cascades over the rocks of the Potomac
images.title: Great Falls of the Potomac
images.caption: The area of Great Falls is one of the reasons for the C&O Canal needed to be built for boat traffic.

images.altText: A replica double decker canal boat is being pulled upstream by mules.
images.title: Charles F. Mercer Replica Canal Boat
images.caption: Mule-drawn canal boat rides are offered at Great Falls Tavern, April through October.

data.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park

data.directionsInfo:
Driving Directions
To reach the visitor center from Interstate 95:
•	Take Exit 3 for US 40
•	Take US 40 East toward “Historic Downtown St. Marys”
•	US 40 becomes Osborne Rd. Continue on until you reach the waterfront
•	Turn right on St. Marys Rd 
•	The visitor center will be two blocks down on your left (113 St. Marys St W, St Marys GA 31558)

entrancePasses.description: The pass is good for one calendar year from month of purchase. The pass admits only the pass holder.
entrancePasses.title: Cumberland Island National Seashore Annual Pass

data.weatherInfo:
Cumberland Island’s climate is hot and humid during summer when temperatures tend to be in the 80's (>26 C) and mild during winter when temperatures tend to be in the 60's (<20 C). The warmest month of the year is July with an average high of 90 degrees F (32 C), while the coldest is January with an average low of 45 degrees F (44 C). Visit the Current Conditions page for an up-to-date local forecast:
https://www.nps.gov/cuis/planyourvisit/conditions.htm#weather
data.name: Cumberland Island

operatingHours.description: The park is open 24 hours a day, all year. The island is only accessible by boat. The visitor center, other facilities, ferry operations, and docks for private boats all have separate hours, however; please see descriptions of those facilities elsewhere.
operatingHours.name: Cumberland Island National Seashore

data.description: St Marys is the gateway to Cumberland Island, Georgia's largest and southernmost barrier island. Here pristine maritime forests, undeveloped beaches and wide marshes whisper the stories of both man and nature. Natives, missionaries, enslaved African Americans and Wealthy Industrialists all walked here.  Cumberland Island is also home to over 9,800 acres of Congressionally designated Wilderness.

images.altText: Sand dunes covered with shrubs and grasses
images.title: Vegetated Dunes
images.caption: Vegetation holds dunes in place providing a barrier to erosion forces and creating essential interdune meadows to support island life.

images.altText: Alligator resting on a log in pond
images.title: Home To Wildlife
images.caption: Cumberland Island National Seashore encompasses a variety of forest, marsh, and coastal landscapes providing a home for numerous species including American Alligators.

images.altText: Ocean beach at sunrise
images.title: Undeveloped Coast
images.caption: Cumberland Island National Seashore encompasses nearly 18 miles of undeveloped beach offering recreation for visitors and essential nesting area for birds and sea turtles.

images.altText: large, white mansion behind oak trees draped with Spanish Moss
images.title: Plum Orchard Mansion
images.caption: Visitors can take a guided tour of the Plum Orchard Mansion and experience the luxuries of Victorian high society as well as the effort and ingenuity it took to make it possible.

images.altText: rippled sands of a beach in front of pine tree covered bluffs
images.title: Island Bluffs Shaped By Tides
images.caption: Tidal forces continue to shape the land today as they have for thousands of years forming high bluffs used for fortifications and ship docking throughout the island’s history.

images.altText: huge oak trees and palm shrubs line a sand road
images.title: Historic Main Road
images.caption: While visitors to the island cannot bring vehicles, they can travel the historic main park road by foot and bicycle. Some remaining island residents will still drive vehicles on the road to reach their residences as they have for generations.

images.altText: brick and stone ruins of a large mansion at sunset under colorful clouds
images.title: Dungeness Ruins
images.caption: Dugeness was the largest mansion built on the island as part of the Carnegie Estate. Though lost to fire in 1959, the ruins of the mansion and several of its support structures are a reminder of the island’s rich history.

images.altText: small white one room church, old red house in the background, under cloudy skies
images.title: The Settlement
images.caption: The remote north end of the island is home to the First African Baptist Church and The Settlement, where African American residents were able to purchase their first deeded property on the island at the end of the 1800s.

images.altText: tidal creek at low tide surrounded by palm and oak trees
images.title: Tidal Creek
images.caption: Rising tides bring valuable nutrients into tidal creeks, while receding tides remove waste. This makes the tide cycle the beating heart of the island’s tidal creeks, salt marshes, and estuaries.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Curecanti. Visitors traveling to East Portal through the Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park entrance must pay $15.00 per vehicle. It covers all persons in a single, private, noncommercial vehicle and is valid for seven calendar days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: U.S. Highway 50 runs the length of Curecanti between Montrose and Gunnison. The recreation area is also accessed from CO Highway 149 and CO Highway 92.
data.weatherInfo:
Weather can vary greatly throughout the day. Summer daytime temperatures range between 50 to 90F (10 to 32C), nights 40 to 60F (4 to 15C). Winter daytime temperatures range between -20 to +40F (-29 to +4C), nights -30 to +20F (-34 to -7C).

Precipitation is minimal, but afternoon thunderstorms and strong winds are common during the summer. Snow accumulation varies greatly year to year. Layered clothing appropriate for the season is recommended.
data.name: Curecanti

operatingHours.description: Open 24 hours per day, 365 days per year, weather permitting.
operatingHours.name: Recreation Area

data.description: Curecanti National Recreation Area is a series of three reservoirs along the once wild Gunnison River. The reservoirs that make up Curecanti today are a destination for water-based recreation high in the Rocky Mountains. Best known for salmon and trout fishing, Curecanti also offers opportunities for hiking, boating, camping, and bird watching.

data.description: Eisenhower National Historic Site preserves the farm of General and 34th President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Adjacent to the Gettysburg battlefield, the farm served the president and first lady as a weekend retreat and as a meeting place for world leaders. With its peaceful setting and view of South Mountain, it was a respite from Washington, DC, and a backdrop for efforts to reduce Cold War tensions.

images.altText: The Eisenhower home with Ike's putting green in the foreground
images.title: Eisenhower home
images.caption: President Eisenhower was an avid golfer and had a putting green added to the backyard.

images.altText: Visitors arrive at the site via the park shuttle bus

The heat gives way to cool, rainy winters with lows near 45º F and highs near 75º F. Fall and spring can bring rain and temperatures from 55-80º F.

data.description: America's only Nobel Prize winning playwright, Eugene O'Neill, chose to live in Northern California at the height of his writing career. Isolated from the world and within the walls of his home, O'Neill wrote his final and most memorable plays; The Iceman Cometh, Long Day's Journey Into Night, and A Moon for the Misbegotten.

images.altText: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California

images.caption: Eugene O'Neill Home in Danville, California

operatingHours.description: Brandywine Valley consists of 1,100 acres of rolling hills and wooded areas are located along the Brandywine River and the arced border between northern Delaware and southern Pennsylvania.
operatingHours.name: Brandywine Valley

operatingHours.description: It was here, along the banks of the Christina River over 375 years ago, that the first Swedish and Finnish American settlers aboard the Kalmar Nyckel and the Fogel Grip landed and settled the first American Swedish colony, New Sweden.
operatingHours.name: Fort Christina

operatingHours.description: The Church known as "the nation's oldest church building still used for worship as originally built" began construction in 1698 and was completed by 1699. The burial ground's 2,000 gravestones reveal hundreds of years of history.
operatingHours.name: Old Swedes Church

exceptions.name: Closed Martin Luther King Jr. Day

operatingHours.description: Historic New Castle served as the colonial capital of Delaware until 1777 and provides valuable stories of our country's earliest settlers and founding fathers. The museum is closed on state holidays.
operatingHours.name: New Castle Court House Museum

operatingHours.description: Home to John Dickinson, known as the "penman of the Revolution" because his writings helped inspire colonial opposition to Great Britain, this site was built in 1739 and located about 6 miles southeast of The Green in Dover.
operatingHours.name: John Dickinson Plantation

operatingHours.description:
This house, built in 1665 in Lewes, Delaware by early Dutch settlers, is thought to be built thirty years after the destruction of the nearby ill-fated Zwaanendael colony, one of the first Dutch settlements in America, and first European settlement in Delaware. Please visit a the "Hours of Operations" page to view a list of dates and hours the house will be open for tours. 

Please visit the Operating Hours & Seasons page for more information: https://www.nps.gov/frst/planyourvisit/hours.htm
operatingHours.name: Ryves Holt House

operatingHours.description: On December 7, 1787, state delegates met on The Green at the Golden Fleece tavern. At this meeting Delaware became the first state to ratify the US Constitution.
operatingHours.name: The Dover Green

data.description: Famous as the First State to ratify the Constitution, Delaware was born out of a conflict among three world powers for dominance of the Delaware Valley.  From this beginning, the region developed a distinct character that tolerated diversity in religion and national origin and valued independence.

images.altText: Rolling agricultural hills on a bright sunny day.
images.title: Brandywine Valley
images.caption: The Brandywine Valley unit is most known for its recreational opportunities.

images.altText: A view of the front of the John Dickinson House on the Plantation.
images.title: John Dickinson Plantation
images.caption: John Dickinson is most famously known as the "penman of the revolution" at this site visitors learn about his early childhood and the enslaved individuals that took care of the grounds.

images.altText: A replica of the original Kalmar Nyckel ship sails by the monument at Fort Christina.
images.title: Fort Christina
images.caption: This site commernmates the Swedes original landing and the fort that once stood in the area.

images.altText: A brick bath leads to a door of an old church surrounded by vegetation.
images.title: Old Swedes Historic Site
images.caption: Old Swedes Historic Site contains burials that can be traced back to the original settlement of the Swedes.

images.altText: Pews line the side of the room leading to the English style court room.
images.title: New Castle Court House
images.caption: The New Castle Court House Museum was the first court of Delaware and has seen a variety of significant moments in history.

images.altText: Red, yellow, and green leaves lay on the grass in front of a colonial building.
images.title: The Dover Green
images.caption: Each fall, an 18th Century Market Fair is recreated to commemorate the original purpose of The Green.

images.altText: A small red house with a green roof.
images.title: Ryves Holt House
images.caption: The Ryves Holt House is said to be the oldest known house in Delaware.

entrancePasses.description: Golden Age Passports are $80 lifetime passes for citizens and permanent residents who are 62 or older.  They will allow a 50% discount for parking fees at both Sandy Hook and Jacob Riis Park.  You may obtain these at any of Gateway's visitor centers, as well as other parks throughout the country.

data.description: Gateway is a large diverse urban park with 27,000 acres spanning Sandy Hook in N.J. and Jamaica Bay and Staten Island in N.Y. It offers green spaces, beaches, wildlife and outdoor recreation, all alongside historic structures and cultural landscapes. It is the 4th most visited National Park Service unit with more than 9.2 million annual visitors. Gateway can be reached by car, ferry, bus or train.

General Grant National Memorial is located in Riverside Park, on the upper west-side of Manhattan. 

The entrance to the mausoleum is between north-bound and south-bound Riverside Drive, near the intersection of West 122nd Street. The visitor center is located to the west, across south-bound Riverside Drive.

Street parking is available, but can be very hard to find. The area is well-served with both Bus and Subway, by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York (http://www.mta.info/).

operatingHours.name: Mausoleum (Tomb)

data.description: The final resting place of President Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia, is the largest mausoleum in North America. It testifies to a people’s gratitude for the man who ended the bloodiest conflict in American history as Commanding General of the Union Army and then, as President of the United States, strove to heal a nation after a civil war and make rights for all citizens a reality.

images.altText: Mausoleum and flags in sunny weather
images.title: Mausoleum
images.caption: The Mausoleum is the final resting place for Ulysses S Grant and his wife Julia D. Grant.

images.altText: Two red stone sarcophagi are in a crypt. A bust of General Sherman can be seen in the distance.
images.title: The Sarcophagi of Ulysses and Julia Grant
images.caption: Two sarcophagi, made of granite from Wisconsin, house the remains of Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia. Bronze busts of key union generals (like William T. Sherman seen here) occupy the  niches in the lower crypt.

images.altText: A circular dome is held up by carvings of allegorical figures.
images.title: The Upper Dome of the Mausoleum
images.caption: The dome of the memorial stretches 150 feet into the sky. On its four corners are four allegorical sculptures, executed by J. Massey Rhind.

images.altText: A neoclassic pavilion sits on the hillside, surrounded by trees with the Hudson River below.
images.title: The Overlook Pavillion, above the Visitor Center
images.caption: The Overlook Pavilion is great place to check out the scenery. Beneath the overlook is the park's visitor center.

images.altText: A black wrought-iron fence surrounds two trees. The enclosure is located directly behind the tomb.
images.title: Site of the Temporary Tomb
images.caption: This enclosure marks the location of the temporary vault where Grant was initially interred. His remains were in the temporary vault for 12 years, from 1885-1897.

images.altText: West Point Cadets in formal uniforms carrying three flags in front of the mausoleum
images.title: U S Military Academy at West Point Colorguard
images.caption: Visit the site on the Birthday Ceremony for U.S. Grant

data.directionsInfo: The Visitor Center is located at the intersection of Truman Road and Main Street, in Historic Fire Station No.1. From the north or south, take I-435 to Truman Road (State Hwy 12), exit 60. Travel east on Truman Road three miles; you'll pass the Truman Home at Delaware Street. From the east or west, take I-70 to the Noland Road exit (12). Travel north on Noland Road four miles to Truman Road. Turn west on Truman Road and travel two blocks. The Truman Home is five blocks to the west of the visitor center.

data.weatherInfo: Located on the western edge of Missouri, the park enjoys each of the four seasons. Early spring brings frequent and rapid fluctuations in weather. The summer season has warm days, periods of high heat and humidity, and mild nights. The fall season is normally mild with sunny days and cool nights. Winters can be cold. The January low averages 21 degrees. The area receives a yearly average of 37 inches of rain per year and around 18 inches of snow.

operatingHours.description: Take a guided tour of the historic Truman Home. With thousands of artifacts on display, the home is an insightful glimpse into the personal lives of the Trumans.  Visitors should stop by the visitor center first to obtain tickets to tour the home.  There are no house tours offered on Mondays between November 1 and the next Memorial Day.  From Memorial Day, through the summer and fall, until November 1, house tours are offered seven days a week.
operatingHours.name: Truman Home - Independence

operatingHours.description:

The Truman Farm Home in Grandview is not open to the public.
operatingHours.name: Truman Farm - Grandview

data.description: President Harry S Truman took America from its traditional isolationism into the age of international involvement. Despite his power, he never forgot where he came from. Today, visitors can experience the surroundings Truman knew as a young man of modest ambition through his political career and final years as a former president.

images.altText: The Truman home near sunset.
images.title: The Truman Home
images.caption: Although Harry Truman was a 20th century president, his home was from the Victorian era.

images.altText: The Truman Farm Home sits behind Autumn trees.
images.title: The Truman Farm Home
images.caption: From when he was 22 until he was 33 years old, Harry Truman lived on his grandmother's farm.

images.altText: The Noland home sits across the street from the Truman home.
images.title: The Noland Home
images.caption: Harry Truman's cousins, the Nolands, lived right across the street from him.

images.altText: The Frank Wallace home where Bess Truman's brother lived.
images.title: The Frank Wallace Home
images.caption: Bess Truman's brother, Frank, and his wife Natalie, lived in this small bungalow right behind the Truman home.

images.altText: The George Wallace home with the Truman home in the background.
images.title: The George Wallace Home
images.caption: Bess Truman's brother, George, and his wife, May, lived right behind the Truman home.

data.description: Although not yet open to the public, Honouliuli National Historic Site will tell the history of internment, martial law, and the experience of prisoners of war in Hawai‘i during World War II. data.description: Maurice D. Hinchey Hudson River Valley National Heritage Area stretches from New York City to Albany. The area's resources exhibit the roles of freedom and dignity in the valley's history, and the historical and contemporary role of commerce. Revolutionary War stories, famous residences, scenic parks and gardens, and landscapes all contribute to the Hudson Valley's beauty and significance.

images.altText: Lookout over the Hudson River

images.caption: The Hudson River Valley is full of natural wonders, historic riches, and cultural treasures

data.description: The Blackstone River runs from Worcester, MA to Providence, RI. Its waters powered the Slater Mill in Pawtucket, RI, America's first successful cotton spinning mill. This creative spark began the nation's transformation from Farm to Factory. Today, the Blackstone River Valley is a special type of National Park - a living landscape containing thousands of natural and historic treasures.

data.weatherInfo: Days are typically clear with less than 25% humidity. Temperatures are most comfortable in the spring and fall, with an average highs around 85°F (29°C) and average lows around 50°F (10°C) respectively. Winter brings cooler days, around 60°F (15°C), and freezing nights. It occasionally snows at higher elevations. Summers are hot, over 100°F (38°C) during the day and not cooling much below 75°F (24°C) at night.
data.name: Joshua Tree

operatingHours.description: Joshua Tree National Park is open 24 hours a day and may be visited at any time of the year. Visitation increases as temperatures moderate in the fall, peaks during the spring wildflower season, and diminishes during the heat of summer. Some areas of the park are designated for day use only. Visitor centers keep separate hours; please see descriptions.
operatingHours.name: Joshua Tree National Park

data.description: Two distinct desert ecosystems, the Mojave and the Colorado, come together in Joshua Tree National Park. A fascinating variety of plants and animals make their homes in a land sculpted by strong winds and occasional torrents of rain. Dark night skies, a rich cultural history, and surreal geologic features add to the wonder of this vast wilderness in southern California. Come explore for yourself.

data.directionsInfo:
Park headquarters and visitor center are located at 2nd and Broadway in Skagway, Alaska. 

To get to Skagway by car: you can access the park via the Alaska Marine Highway or the South Klondike Highway. By plane: you can fly into the Skagway Airport. By water: You can visit the park by cruise ship, tour boat, or ferry. The park visitor center is less than half a mile from all docks.
data.weatherInfo: Skagway has a highly variable climate with frequent rain and high winds.  Average temperatures May through September range from 47 F to 60 F.  Average temperatures October through April range from 28 F to 38 F.
data.name: Klondike Gold Rush

operatingHours.description:
The park is open year round.  

Visitor services are most abundant early May through late September.  

Limited visitor services are offered October through April.  Visit https://www.nps.gov/klgo/planyourvisit/wintervisits.htm for more information on visiting in the winter.

data.description: Headlines screamed "Gold!" The dream of a better life catapulted thousands of people to Alaska and the Yukon Territory. Their journey shaped them, and changed the people they encountered and the north forever. Today, the park remembers the trails, boomtowns, and stories of the Klondike Gold Rush.

data.directionsInfo: Kobuk Valley National Park is very remote. There are no roads to provide access, so planes take care of most transportation needs.  Commercial airlines provide service from Anchorage to Kotzebue, or from Fairbanks to Bettles. Once in Kotzebue or Bettles, you must fly to the park with authorized air taxis.
data.weatherInfo: Snow, rain, and freezing temperatures can occur any time of the year. Always travel with good quality rain gear and warm layers. Be especially careful to stay dry. Hypothermia can set in on a windy, wet day, even when it doesn't feel that cold.
data.name: Kobuk Valley

operatingHours.description: The Northwest Arctic Heritage Center is the visitor center for Kobuk Valley National Park.  Since there are no roads in to Kobuk Valley, the visitor center is located in Kotzebue, AK.  From Kotzebue, visitors will charter an air taxi to transport them into the actual national park which is open 24/7 every day of the year.
operatingHours.name: Kobuk Valley National Park

data.description: Caribou, sand dunes, the Kobuk River, Onion Portage - just some of the facets of Kobuk Valley National Park. Half a million caribou migrate through, their tracks crisscrossing sculpted dunes. The Kobuk River is an ancient and current path for people and wildlife. For 9000 years, people came to Onion Portage to harvest caribou as they swam the river. Even today, that rich tradition continues.

images.altText: sun setting on sand dunes
images.title: Kobuk Sand Dunes
images.caption: The setting sun casts shadows of black spruce on the dunes and colors the water of Ahnewetut Creek a deep blue.

images.altText: aerial view of snow capped mountains
images.title: Mountains as Far as the Eye Can See
images.caption: The peaks of the Baird Mountains stretch far into the distance and are so remote that many of them have not been named.

images.altText: Caribou bone sitting in the sand
images.title: Left Behind
images.caption: Caribou migrate across the Great Kobuk Sand Dunes, heading north in the summer and south in the fall. Some survive and some don't, which is a reality of life

images.altText: Single caribou with antlers in velvet
images.title: Lone Rangifer tarandus
images.caption: A single caribou of the 240,000+ strong Western Arctic herd on its fall migration south across Kobuk Valley National Park.

images.altText: pink flower growing in sand
images.title: Kobuk Locoweed
images.caption: Oxytropis kobukensis (Kobuk Locoweed) is a member of the pea family and adds a splash of pink to the sand dunes. The blossoms have that typical pea/ bean flower shape that many gardeners know.

data.directionsInfo:
From Interstate Route 495 take Exit 35C on to the Lowell Connector.
From Route 3 take Exit 30A if traveling southbound, Exit 30B if traveling northbound.
 
• Take the Lowell Connector to Exit 5B (Thorndike Street).
• Continue right on to Thorndike Street, which becomes Dutton Street.
• At the third traffic light continue straight under the overpass.
• At the next light turn right into the Visitor Center Parking Lot.
data.weatherInfo:
Summer: Throughout the summer, temperatures range from the mid 60s to mid 90s during the day, with rain and thunderstorms more common in the months of July and August. Boats and trolleys operate rain or shine and are only cancelled in cases of extreme weather or the presence of thunder and lightning.
 
Winter: Winters are typically cold with temperatures in the mid 30s and 40s (with occasional single digit temperatures) and snow storms with a few inches accumulation occur frequently throughout the season.
data.name: Lowell
data.description: Discover the Continuing Revolution. Lowell’s water-powered textile mills catapulted the nation – including immigrant families and early female factory workers – into an uncertain new industrial era. Nearly 200 years later, the changes that began here still reverberate in our shifting global economy. Explore Lowell, a living monument to the dynamic human story of the Industrial Revolution.

images.altText: Group of visitors on a boat on a canal with large brick factory buildings on either side.
images.title: Industrial Canyon Tour
images.caption: A ranger-guided trip down the Industrial Canyon on part of Lowell's 5.6 mile canal system is one of the signature experiences at Lowell National Historical Park.

images.altText: 5 story brick factories with a clocktower surrounding a central courtyard
images.title: Boott Cotton Mills
images.caption: The Boott Cotton Mills is one of the best, most-intact complexes of cotton mills from Lowell's heyday in the 19th century.

images.altText: Streetcar guided through Lowell by motormen with lots of passengers
images.title: Lowell NHP Trolley
images.caption: Lowell National Historical Park operates reproduction vintage streetcars throughout the park and downtown Lowell. Climb onboard for a ride or a ranger-guided tour.

images.altText: Two young visitors look over the rail at a room full of working looms
images.title: Boott Mills Weave Room
images.caption: The working weave room at the Boott Cotton Mills Museum surrounds you with the sights and sounds of a turn-of-the-century working cotton textile factory.

images.altText: Two students weaving on the looms at the education center.
images.title: Tsongas Center Programs
images.caption: The Tsongas Industrial History Center, a partnership of Lowell National Historical Park and UMass Lowell's Graduate School of Education, offers hands-on interactive education workshops for more than 50,000 students each year.

images.altText: Street scene with lots of tents and crowds listening to Folk Festival music at Boardinghouse Park.
images.title: Lowell Folk Festival
images.caption: The Lowell Folk Festival, Lowell's signature annual event, brings traditional folk performers to 5 stages throughout the city and a huge variety of traditional ethnic foods from all around the world.

data.directionsInfo:
By car to National Park Headquarters and the Visitor Center in Johnson City:

From Austin, take Highway 290 west.
From San Antonio, take Highway 281 north.
From Fredericksburg, take Highway 290 east. 

By car to the LBJ Ranch and LBJ State Park and Historic Site:

From Johnson City, take Highway 290 fourteen miles west to the LBJ State Park.
From Fredericksburg, take Highway 290 sixteen miles east to the LBJ State Park.

The nearest major airports are in Austin and San Antonio.
data.weatherInfo:
Overall, the park enjoys a sunny, mild climate during three seasons of the year.

Spring: Temperatures range from 45 F to 85 F (7 C/29 C). Rain is common in April and May.

Summer: Temperatures range from 70 F to 95 F (21 C/35 C). Temperatures can exceed 100 F (38 C) in July and August. Lightweight clothing and sunscreen are advisable. Be prepared with plenty of water.

Fall: Temperatures range from 45 F to 85 F (7 C/29 C).

Winter: Temperatures range from 35 F to 65 F (2 C/18 C) . Snow and ice are rare.

data.description:
---Lyndon Baines Johnson

Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park tells the story of our 36th President beginning with his ancestors until his final resting place on his beloved LBJ Ranch. This entire "circle of life" gives the visitor a unique perspective into one of America's most noteworthy citizens by providing the most complete picture of any American president.

images.altText: View of Texas White House from front lawn.
images.title: Texas White House
images.caption: Because President Johnson spent one-fourth of his term a president in Texas, the press referred to this home as the "Texas White House"

images.altText: View of Boyhood Home from the front street.
images.title: Boyhood Home
images.caption: Lyndon Johnson was 5 years old when he moved to this home with his family. His childhood in a small rural town had great impact on his futur.

images.altText: A park visitor meets one of the ranch's Hereford cattle while driving the tour route.
images.title: Touring the LBJ Ranch
images.caption: A park visitor meets one of the ranch's Hereford cattle while driving the tour route.

images.altText: Luci Johnson (center in gray jersey) leads a bike tour
images.title: Cyclists in the LBJ 100
images.caption: Many special events, such as the LBJ 100 bike ride, take place during the year.

images.altText: Pink granite headstones mark the graves of President Lyndon Johnson and First Lady Lady Bird Johnson
images.title: Gravestones for Lyndon and Lady Bird Johnson
images.caption: Pink granite headstones mark the graves of President Lyndon Johnson and First Lady Lady Bird Johnson

images.credit: LBJ Library Photo by Frank Wolfe
images.altText: President and Mrs. Johnson stand outside the Texas White House with dog Yuki.
images.title: Portrait of the Johnsons
images.caption: For their 1972 Christmas card, the Johnsons stand outside the Texas White House with their dog Yuki.

images.altText: View of the Pedernales River
images.title: Pedernales River
images.caption: The Pedernales River forms flows past the LBJ Ranch

images.altText: An exterior view of a Lockheed Jetstar used by President Johnson.
images.title: Lockheed Jetstar
images.caption: One of the five Lockheed Jetstars in service during the Johnson Presidency is now on display at the LBJ Ranch..

data.weatherInfo:
Spring: Mild weather, with average low/high temperatures from 33 F to 75 F.  Variable rainfall, with May being the wettest month of the year on average.

Summer: Warm and humid weather, with average temperatures from 61 F to 88 F.  Variable rainfall, with occasional downpours during storms.

Fall: Mild weather, with average temperatures from 35 F to 79 F.  Variable rainfall.

Winter: Mild to cool weather, with average temperatures from 24 F to 47 F.  Annual snowfall averages about 22 inches.

operatingHours.description: The park is open daily from dawn until dusk.
operatingHours.name: Manassas National Battlefield Park

data.description: On July 21, 1861, two armies clashed for the first time on the fields overlooking Bull Run. Heavy fighting swept away any notion of a quick war. In August 1862, Union and Confederate armies converged for a second time on the plains of Manassas. The Confederates won a solid victory bringing them to the height of their power.

images.altText: Bronze statue of Gen. T. J. "Stonewall" Jackson on horseback in an open field.
images.title: Stonewall Jackson Monument
images.caption: The statue of Confederate Gen. T. J. "Stonewall" Jackson stands on Henry Hill, near the spot where he earned his famous nickname.

images.altText: Red sandstone obelisk surrounded by post and rail fence.
images.title: Bull Run Monument
images.caption: The Bull Run Monument on Henry Hill is among the nation's earliest Civil War monuments.

images.altText: View of Stone House, with worm rail fence and well in front yard.
images.title: Stone House
images.caption: The historic Stone House, a battlefield landmark, sheltered Union wounded in both battles of Manassas.

images.altText: Civil War cannon and granite and bronze monument under a cloudy sky.
images.title: 14th Brooklyn Monument
images.caption: The 14th Brooklyn Monument overlooks the scene of heavy fighting near Groveton during Second Manassas.

images.altText: Rustic farmhouse, flanked by shade tree, stone monument, and white outbuilding, on top of a hill.
images.title: Henry House
images.caption: The Henry House, built over the ruins of the wartime dwelling, welcomed returning veterans to the battlefield after the war.

data.directionsInfo: Minidoka National Historic Site is located between the towns of Twin Falls and Jerome, Idaho in south central Idaho. There are minimal facilities and services at the site. Many buildings and features that were part of the center are located on private property surrounding the Historic Site. Please do not enter any private property.
data.weatherInfo: Jerome and Twin Falls, Idaho, gets 10 inches of rain per year. On average, there are 213 sunny days per year here. The July high is around 94 degrees. The January low is 22. Our comfort index, which is based on humidity during the hot months, is a 78 out of 100, where higher is more comfortable. The US average on the comfort index is 44.
data.name: Minidoka

operatingHours.description:
The Historic Site is open daily during daylight hours year-round.
It is still being developed. Please be prepared. Wear sturdy footwear and bring water. 
There is little - no shade at the site. The Historic Site is located on a county road. It may not be well maintained during winter weather. Please check road conditions before venturing there.
operatingHours.name: Minidoka National Historic Site

data.description:
The Pearl Harbor attack intensified existing hostility towards Japanese Americans. As wartime hysteria mounted, President Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066 forcing over 120,000 West Coast persons of Japanese ancestry (Nikkei) to leave their homes, jobs, and lives behind, forcing them into one of ten prison camps spread across the nation because of their ethnicity.  

This is Minidoka's story.

Our main visitor center, Kelso Depot, is located inside the Preserve, 95 miles north of Barstow, and 90 miles south of Las Vegas, at the intersection of Kelso-Cima and Kelbaker Roads.

data.weatherInfo: Mojave Desert experiences change with the seasons. In winter, freezing temperatures and strong winds can be expected, with rain and snow in the mountains. With enough moisture, spring wildflowers may carpet the desert floor with vivid colors. Summers are hot, and temperatures above 100 degrees Fahrenheit are typical. In summer, adventurers head for the higher elevations such as Mid-Hills and the New York Mountains. The cooler temperatures of fall mark hunting season.
data.name: Mojave

operatingHours.description: Mojave National Preserve is always open.
operatingHours.name: Park Operating Hours

data.description: Singing sand dunes, cinder cone volcanoes, a large Joshua tree forest, and carpets of spring wildflowers are all found within this 1.6-million-acre park. A visit to its canyons, mountains, and mesas will reveal long-abandoned mines, homesteads, and rock-walled military outposts. Located between Los Angeles and Las Vegas, Mojave provides serenity and solitude from major metropolitan areas.

images.altText: Spring wildflowers carpeting the desert floor
images.title: A desert road surrounded by spring wildflowers
images.caption: Many people visit Mojave in the spring season to view stunning wildflower displays.

images.altText: A lonely desert trail leads to tall sand dunes
images.title: Hiking Opportunities Abound
images.caption: Mojave has endless options for hikers. Kelso Sand Dunes are a popular trail in cooler months.

images.altText: A desert tortoise rest in the shade of a bush near some hikers
images.title: Desert Wildlife
images.caption: Mojave has a great diversity of wildlife. In spring and fall, the elusive desert tortoise can be seen foraging food.

images.altText: A man standing on a mountain peak in front of a wide desert landscape
images.title: Stunning Vistas
images.caption: Mojave is a hiker's paradise. With no less than 9 named mountain ranges int he park, there's no shortage of amazing views to be had.

images.altText: A Joshua tree seen though the window of an old miner's cabin
images.title: Rich Human History
images.caption: Visitors can still hear the echos of history here. Evidence of days long past still persist in Mojave. Native American petroglyphs, long-abandoned mines, and cattle ranches still dot the landscape.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to hike the New England Trail. Overnight site fees vary, please visit http://www.newenglandtrail.org/get-on-the-trail/overnight-sites, for details and fees.
entranceFees.title: New England Trail Fees

data.directionsInfo: More than 100 public roads cross the New England Trail, and there are trail head parking areas at or near many of these crossings. Detailed Trail Maps are available from Appalachian Mountain Club and Connecticut Forest & Park Association. For Massachusetts maps, visit the AMC Berkshire Chapter; for Connecticut, visit the CFPA Bookstore. Direct access by bus is available at several points in Connecticut and Massachusetts. Train service is available at two points – in Guilford, CT and Northampton, MA.

data.description: From the Sound to the Summits: the New England Trail covers 215 miles from Long Island Sound across long ridges to scenic mountain summits in Connecticut and Massachusetts. The trail offers panoramic vistas and close-ups of New England’s natural and cultural landscape: traprock ridges, historic village centers, farmlands, unfragmented forests, quiet streams, steep river valleys and waterfalls.

data.description: A rugged, whitewater river flowing northward through deep canyons, the New River is among the oldest rivers on the continent. The park encompasses over 70,000 acres of land along the New River, is rich in cultural and natural history, and offers an abundance of scenic and recreational opportunities.

entranceFees.description: There are no fees to visit any of the sites of Nez Perce National Historical Park. Also, as of 2007 Big Hole National Battlefield stopped collecting entrance fees. Entrance to the battlefield is now free!
entranceFees.title: Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo:
Driving south bound on  U.S. Highway 95 you will find the Visitor Center 10 miles from Lewiston, ID.  Roughly one mile after crossing the Clearwater River you will find the park entrance on your left.

When driving north on U.S. Highway 95 the Visitor Center will be 3 miles north of Lapwai, ID.  The park entrance will be on your right.
data.weatherInfo:
Elevations in the Park range from 700 feet above sea level to over 8,000, providing a wide range of climatic conditions, that follow the four seasons.
Be prepared for very warm weather in the summer months, in particular in the river valleys. The spring and fall are moderate and comfortable. Winter conditions can be severe in the higher elevations, with snow and ice making travel difficult and dangerous.
Please visit the National Weather Service for comprehensive weather information.

operatingHours.description: The Spalding Visitor Center operating hours in the summer are 8:30am-4:00pm daily. In the winter, the visitor center has the same hours but is closed Sunday-Monday.The visitor center is also closed on Thanksgiving day, Christmas day, and New Year's day.
operatingHours.name: Nez Perce National Historical Park, Spalding Visitor Center

data.description: Since time immemorial, the valleys, prairies, mountains, and plateaus of the inland northwest have been home to the Nimiipuu (Nez Perce) people. Extremely resilient, they survived the settling of the United States and adapted to a changed world. Nez Perce National Historical Park consists of 38 places important to the history and culture of the Nimiipuu. Explore these places. Learn their stories.

entranceFees.description:
There is no fee to visit the Outdoor Symbolic Memorial. 

There is, however, a $15.00 to enter the Oklahoma City National Memorial and Museum which is owned and operated by the Oklahoma City National Memorial Foundation.
entranceFees.title: Oklahoma City National Memorial: Outdoor Symbolic Memorial Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo: The Memorial & Museum are located at 6th St. and Harvey Ave in Oklahoma City, OK.
data.weatherInfo: Summers are very warm with temperatures averaging low- mid 90’s. Also, be mindful of the heat index. Spring weather brings mild temperatures, 60’s-70’s, but the ability to produce severe storms that could include heavy rains, strong winds, hail, and tornadoes. While winters are generally mild delivering temperatures in the 40’s and 50’s, the wind chill can be brutal. No matter the season you are planning to visit, be prepared for the winds to be gusting.
data.name: Oklahoma City

operatingHours.description: The Outdoor Symbolic Memorial is open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year.
operatingHours.name: Oklahoma City National Memorial: Outdoor Symbolic Memorial

data.description: The outdoor symbolic memorial is a place of quiet reflection, honoring victims, survivors, rescuers, and all who were changed forever on April 19, 1995. It encompasses the now sacred soil where the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building once stood, capturing and preserving forever the place and events that changed the world.

images.altText: Tiles with hand prints and chalkboards set into the ground for children.
images.title: Children's Area
images.caption: This area provides letter shaped chalkboards to allow the continued emotional expressions from those young and old. A surrounding wall displays a collection of painted tiles sent by schools, showing their compassion for the bombing-affected community

images.altText: Fencing with pictures, stuffed animals and other tokens left on it.
images.title: Memorial Fence
images.caption: This 200 foot section of chain link fence was taken from the original barrier surrounding the bombing site. The fence served as the first spontaneous memorial and a location for people to leave tokens of collective grief. It retains this purpose still to

images.altText: Summer evening photo of the Memorial lit up at night
images.title: Summer Nights
images.caption: Beat the summer heat, on an evening stroll through the illuminated Field of Empty Chairs, the Gates of Time, and the Survivor Tree. All walkways are brightened to allow enjoyment of this peaceful time of day.

images.altText: Snow covered Field of Empty Chairs
images.title: Snow on Empty Chairs
images.caption: The Memorial becomes a silent place during the rare winter snow storms that blow through. The cold and quiet house a stillness made for reflection as one walks through the Field of Empty Chairs.

images.altText: Bright Red Chinese Pastiche tree in the Rescuers' Orchard.
images.title: Rescuers' Orchard in Fall
images.caption: This Chinese Pastiche is located in the small orchard that was planted in recognition of the over 12,000 rescue workers who responded to the bombing. Its vibrant hues draw attention to the tremendous work these heroes accomplished.

entranceFees.title: Rainbow Bridge Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo:
Rainbow Bridge National Monument is located between Glen Canyon National Recreation Area and the Navajo Nation. There are no roads in the vicinity of the monument. Rainbow Bridge can be reached by boat on Lake Powell or by hiking one of two trails around Navajo Mountain on the Navajo Nation, by permit only. Boat tours are available.

The entrance to Forbidding Canyon is located at buoy 49 on Lake Powell. Boaters should be familiar with the Aids to Navigation (buoy) system and use a navigational map.

entrancePasses.description: As there are no fees for Rainbow Bridge, there is no pass.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Pass

data.weatherInfo: Summers are extremely hot with little, if any, shade. Winters are moderately cold with night time lows often below freezing. Spring weather is highly variable with extended periods of strong winds. Fall is generally mild. Temperatures range from 110°F (43°C) in June & July to 20°F (-7°C) in December & January. Although precipitation is generally less than 6 inches (15cm) annually, both heavy rains and flash flooding can occur, particularly during the summer monsoon season.
data.name: Rainbow Bridge

operatingHours.description: Rainbow Bridge National Monument is open every day of the year, from sunrise to sunset. On rare occasions, the park may be closed for visitor safety while significant trail and/or dock repairs are taking place. Contact the park for up to date information on any closures in effect.
operatingHours.name: Rainbow Bridge National Monument

data.description:
Rainbow Bridge is one of the world's largest known natural bridges. The span has undoubtedly inspired people throughout time--from the neighboring American Indian tribes who consider Rainbow Bridge sacred, to the 85,000 people from around the world who visit it each year.

Please visit Rainbow Bridge in a spirit that honors and respects the cultures to whom it is sacred.

images.altText: A large sandstone arch - a natural bridge.
images.title: Rainbow Bridge
images.caption: Stand here and take in the majesty of Rainbow Bridge - the largest natural bridge in the National Park Service.

images.altText: A view of Rainbow Bridge from the air.
images.title: Aerial View of Rainbow Bridge
images.caption: Seen from the air, Rainbow Bridge is a graceful curve over the dry stream bed.

images.altText: A large crowd faces away from the camera at the scenery.
images.title: A Crowd Views Rainbow Bridge From Its Shadow
images.caption: In the desert heat after the rough walk up to Rainbow Bridge from the docks, you take shade where you can get it.

images.altText: Boats and personal watercraft sidle up to docks.
images.title: Rainbow Bridge Docks
images.caption: The only way to access Rainbow Bridge is by a two-day hike across the Navajo Nation, or a fifty-mile boat trip up Lake Powell.

images.altText: An elderly Native American man sits in a lawn chair under Rainbow Bridge
images.title: Jim Mike Returns to Rainbow Bridge
images.caption: In 1974, Ute Mountain Ute Jim Mike, one of the  guides who led the original expedition to Rainbow Bridge, returned to see how he had led the way for many more visitors.

data.name: Reconstruction Era
data.description: The Reconstruction era,1861-1900 the historic period in which the United States grappled with the question of how to integrate millions of newly freed African Americans into social, political,economic, and labor systems, was a time of significant transformation. The people, places, and events in Beaufort County, South Carolina, reflect on the most important issues of this tumultuous time period.

data.weatherInfo:
Variable
-- February-April: High temperatures range from mid-70sF (23C) to low-90sF (32C) with lows from the mid-30sF (2C) to mid-50sF (12C). Cold fronts can bring freezing weather with rain or snow.
-- May-August: Temperatures are hot and the weather can be stormy. Temperatures over 100F (more than 38C) degrees.
-- September-January:Temperatures are cooler. The weather can turn cold any time during these months.

data.description: It is an irresistible playground where unruly rapids check your skills as a canyon wren’s definitive call cascades down ancient limestone cliffs. Below the chasm, the canyon’s raw beauty dances across mirrored water. While the primal nature of the river stirs hunger for spirited adventure, the river is also an undulant ribbon of wetland corridor and, against all odds, the lifeblood of the desert.

data.description: Since 1665, Saint Paul's Church played a vital role in the colonial life of Eastchester, 20 miles north of New York City. Townspeople voted at the nearby Village Green; local militia drilled outside its doors. But the American Revolution changed everything. American, British and Hessian troops tore down the old wooden meetinghouse for firewood and used the unfinished stone chapel as a hospital.

images.altText: Rebecca Turner gravesite
images.title: Rebecca Turner gravesite
images.caption: A former enslaved person, Rebecca Turner attended the church and is buried in the cemetery. A local elementary school is named after her.

images.altText: Saint Paul's Church National Historic Site
images.title: Saint Paul's Church National Historic Site
images.caption: The church was originally a wooden meetinghouse. This stone structure was still unfinished when US, British and Hessian troops used it for a hospital during the Revolution.

images.altText: Encampment volley
images.title: Encampment volley
images.caption: History is a blast, especially when costumed Revolutionary War interpreters visit the site during a special event.

images.altText: Local students gather inside Saint Paul's Church
images.title: Local students gather inside Saint Paul's Church
images.caption: In 2015, local students visited the site to honor Rebecca and Benjamin Turner, two former members of Saint Paul's Church. Local schools have been named after the couple.

images.altText: The restored church pews
images.title: The restored church pews
images.caption: The pews have been rebuilt to resemble what was here when the stone church was first opened.

data.fullName: Saint Paul's Church National Historic Site

January: 37 high, 20 low
February: 40 high, 23 low
March: 47 high, 30 low
April: 57 high, 38 low
May: 67 high, 48 low
June: 76 high, 58 low
July: 82 high, 63 low
August: 80 high, 62 low
September: 73 high, 55 low
October: 62 high, 45 low
November: 52 high, 37 low

data.description: In the 1600's, on the banks of the Saugus River, something extraordinary happened.  Explore the place where European iron makers brought their special skills to a young Massachusetts colony. This nine-acre National Park includes working waterwheels, forges, mills, an historic 17th century home, and a lush river basin.

data.description: The Battle of Stones River began on the last day of 1862 and was one of the bloodiest conflicts of the Civil War. The battle produced important military and political gains for the Union, and it changed forever the people who lived and fought here.

images.altText: The sun rises behind a green field with a cannon in the foreground.
images.title: Sunrise at Mendenhall's Artillery Trail
images.caption: On January 2, 1863, fifty-seven Union cannons fired from this line ending the Battle of Stones River by killing or wounding more than 1,800 Confederates in less than an hour.

images.altText: A ray of sunlight shines on the ground at Stones River National Cemetery.
images.title: Stones River National Cemetery
images.caption: More than 6,100 Union soldiers lie in Stones River National Cemetery.

images.altText: Two cannons sit in an icy field.
images.title: The Chicago Board of Trade Battery
images.caption: The men of the Chicago Board of Trade Battery got their first taste of combat at the Battle of Stones River and helped stem the Confederate tide from this position during the afternoon of December 31, 1862.

images.altText: Union soldiers fire muskets.
images.title: Union Infantry Program
images.caption: Living history programs help visitors visualize the trials of soldiers during the Battle of Stones River.

images.altText: Bicyclists ride down a road bracketed by trees.
images.title: Bike Tour
images.caption: Thousands of visitors enjoy biking and hiking through the park.

data.weatherInfo: Be prepared for variable and extreme weather conditions. You may expect high winds any time of year, summer temperatures above 95ºF (35ºC), afternoon storms July–September, and heavy snow from fall to spring. Dress in layers, as weather at Walnut Canyon can change quickly at any time of year.
data.name: Walnut Canyon

operatingHours.description:
Walnut Canyon National Monument is open daily from 9 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Access to park's trails and views of the canyon are not accessible outside of operating hours. 

Access to the Island Trail closes at 3:30 pm; access to the Rim Trail closes at 4:30 pm to help ensure visitors are off the trails before the park gates are closed at 4:30 pm.

*The park is closed on December 25th and January 1st.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

data.description: Come gaze across curved canyon walls. Among the remarkable geological formations of the canyon itself, the former homes of ancient inhabitants are easily evident. Along the trails you can imagine life within Walnut Canyon, while visiting actual pueblos and walking in the steps of those who came before.

images.altText: sunlight illuminates stone walls in a canyon cliff dwelling
images.title: Cliff Dwellings
images.caption: Walnut Canyon National Monument protects a series of ancient cliff dwellings built between 1125 and 1250 CE.

images.altText: a circular overlook at the edge of the canyon rim
images.title: Walnut Canyon Rim Overlook
images.caption: The 0.7-mile (1.1 km) Rim Trail reveals expansive views of Walnut Canyon and its cliff dwellings.

images.altText: warm sunlight illuminates a cliff dwelling wall beside a snowy trail
images.title: Walnut Canyon Snow
images.caption: The 0.9-mile (1.4 km) Island Trail leads visitors down 240 stairs to explore 25 cliff dwelling rooms.

images.altText: a common raven landing on a barren juniper branch
images.title: Walnut Canyon Raven
images.caption: At the rim of Walnut Canyon, visitors stand at eye level with soaring ravens, eagles, and other birds

images.altText: a visitor looks out over Walnut Canyon from the trail
images.title: A Visitor at Walnut Canyon
images.caption: More than 125,000 people visit Walnut Canyon each year.

data.description: More than a museum, the Wing is an experience. A chance to truly understand what it was - and is - to be Asian American in the Pacific Northwest. Take a guided tour of a historic hotel and learn the inside story about what makes the local Chinatown-International District unique. Visitors explore thought-provoking exhibitions of real stories, including actor and martial arts master Bruce Lee.
