data.description:
Wind, sand, and a dream of flight brought Wilbur and Orville Wright to Kitty Hawk, North Carolina where, after four years of scientific experimentation, they achieved the first successful airplane flights on December 17, 1903.

With courage and perseverance, these self-taught engineers relied on teamwork and application of the scientific process. What they achieved changed our world forever.

images.credit: Wilbur Wright, Orville Wright, and John Daniels
images.altText: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time as Wilbur assists.
images.title: First Flight
images.caption: Orville takes to the air in the flyer for the first time on December 17, 1903.

images.altText: Copper busts of the two brothers with the moon visible in the blue sky.
images.title: Busts and Moon
images.caption: Copper busts of Wilbur and Orville Wright stand atop Big Kill Devil Hill.

images.altText: The large boulder and plaque sit where the Wright brothers first flew in their 1903 flyer.
images.title: First Flight Boulder
images.caption: This boulder marks the spot where the Wright brothers first flew in their 1903 flyer.

images.altText: Visitors walk along the flight line where Wilbur and Orville Wright flew and landed.
images.title: Walking Along History
images.caption: Visitors explore the landing spots of the Wright brothers' first flights.

images.altText: View straight up at the monument with the Sun directly behind the stonework.
images.title: Wright Brothers Monument
images.caption: Black-and-white image of the Wright Brothers Monument

images.altText: Two young girls look across the grounds of Wright Brothers National Memorial.
images.title: National Aviation Day
images.caption: Visitors enjoy celebrating aviation where modern aviation was born.

images.altText: Visitors moving along a sidewalk to the top of the hill where the monument stands.
images.title: Journey to the Top
images.caption: Visitors climb Big Kill Devil Hill to visit the Wright Brothers Monument.

data.weatherInfo: Be prepared for variable and extreme weather conditions. You may expect high winds any time of year, summer temperatures above 100ºF (38ºC), afternoon storms July–September, and occasional snow in winter and early spring. Dress in layers, as Wupatki weather can change quickly at any time of year.
data.name: Wupatki

operatingHours.description:
The Wupatki National Monument Visitor Center is open 9:00AM to 5:00PM MST year round except for December 25th and January 1st. 

Trails to Wupatki, Wukoki, Citadel, Nalakihu, Box Canyon, and Lomaki Pueblos are open daily from sunrise to sunset
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

data.description: Nestled between the Painted Desert and ponderosa highlands of northern Arizona, Wupatki is a landscape of legacies. Ancient pueblos dot red-rock outcroppings across miles of prairie. Where food and water seem impossible to find, people built pueblos, raised families, farmed, traded, and thrived. Today, if you linger and listen, earth and artifacts whisper their stories to us still.

images.altText: a large stone pueblo in a desert beneath partly cloudy skies
images.title: Wupatki Pueblo
images.caption: Wupatki, the monument's namesake pueblo, is made up of more than 100 rooms. The trail also features an ancient ball court and natural blowhole.

images.altText: a man and woman walking toward a three-story sandstone tower
images.title: Wukoki Pueblo
images.caption: Wukoki Pueblo is located three miles from the Wupatki Visitor Center.

images.altText: a stone pueblo beneath a dark blue sky
images.title: Lomaki Pueblo
images.caption: Lomaki means "beautiful house" in the Hopi language. The pueblo is located ten miles from the visitor center and is reachable via a short, 0.25-mile trail.

images.altText: stars and the Milky Way galaxy over a desert juniper tree
images.title: Dark Skies over the Desert
images.caption: Wupatki National Monument features exceptionally dark night skies and hosts numerous star parties each year.

images.altText: T-shaped doorways in adjoining pueblo walls beneath a clear sky
images.title: Crack-In-Rock Pueblo
images.caption: Each April and October, park rangers guide visitors into the Wupatki back country on overnight hikes to Crack-In-Rock Pueblo.

entranceFees.description: There is no entrance fee for Yucca House National Monument.
entranceFees.title: No Entrance Fee

data.directionsInfo:
•From Cortez, take Hwy. 491 south approximately 8 miles. 
•Take a right on MC County Road B (green sign), which is a dirt road one mile south of MC Road C. 
•Drive 0.8 miles, crossing a paved road (MC Road 21), and take the next dirt road on the right (before the farmhouse on the left). 
•Follow this road north and west for 1.4 miles, and head towards a white ranch house with a red roof on the west horizon.
•Once at the ranch house, Yucca House NM is on the left side if the driveway.

data.weatherInfo: Spring and Fall are mild with daytime temperatures ranging from 50 F to 80 F.  Winter temperatures are below 50 F with occasional snowstorms.  Summers are hot and dry, with highs in the 90s.

operatingHours.name: Yucca House National Monument

data.description: Through a continuing tradition of public and private cooperation, Yucca House National Monument preserves one of the largest archeological sites in SW Colorado. The unexcavated nature of the site preserves its integrity and beauty for future generations of scientists and visitors. Experience a sense of discovery by visiting a site that has remained largely untouched for the past 800 years!

images.caption: Ancient walls of Yucca House still standing today.

images.title: Ancestral Puebloan Wall at Yucca House
images.caption: View of an Ancestral Puebloan wall still standing at Yucca House.

images.title: Yucca House in Context
images.caption: The Yucca House archeological site is surrounded by agricultural land today.

data.weatherInfo:
Zion is known for a wide range of weather conditions. Temperatures vary with changes in elevation and day/night temperatures may differ by over 30°F.

In summer, temperatures in Zion National Park often exceed 100°F/38°C. Zion experiences monsoons from mid-July into September that results in an increased risk of flash floods. Always be aware of the threat of storms and lightning and be prepared for a wide range of weather conditions. Winters are generally mild.
data.name: Zion

operatingHours.description: Zion National Park is open every day of the year.

data.description: Follow the paths where ancient native people and pioneers walked. Gaze up at massive sandstone cliffs of cream, pink, and red that soar into a brilliant blue sky. Experience wilderness in a narrow slot canyon. Zion’s unique array of plants and animals will enchant you as you absorb the rich history of the past and enjoy the excitement of present day adventures.
